It has been suggested that the earliest, largest, and longest-lived cities were founded and grew within and on the borders of marshlands (
5 ,
6 ). Marshes buffered large-scale fluctuations in precipitation or shifts in water supply. They were a permanent source of water for irrigation and a supplier of food and building materials (
14 ). Permanent access to a source of water was key to human health and sustained food production for many thousands of years (
7 ,
15 ,
16 ). Was this idyllic situation sustainable over several millennia?
